title: "What are the limitations of De Martino's ethnological approach and his understanding of 'magical world'?"
first_phrase: In the previous section, we learned about De Martino, an ethno logist who collects data from various explorers and observes the ways of primitive populations. However, his work has some limitations, as he speaks of the "magical world" instead of the "witch world" and assumes these primitive societies are remnants of a past civilization left behind in the progress of humanity. In the last 200 tokens, the author expands on the limitations of De Martino's work, who ignores the ancient sacred sciences of traditional civilisations and the existence of some present-day ambient with unbroken transmission of these sciences. Instead, De Martino seems only to be aware of mediums and psychics.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the truth is that the concept of "primitive" is just an extreme form of degeneration and decline of previous races and civilizations, and the "material" that De Martino uses in his research is limited to degraded fragments of structures that belonged to a different realm. Despite his limited perspective, he correctly argues that our concept of reality is historically conditioned and that the "magical civilization" has a different understanding of the self, nature, and reality. Therefore, when dealing with abnormal phenomena, we should not place them within the narrow scope of our modern worldview but acknowledge their reality according to a different understanding of the world.
